labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Connection Attribute
issues.author: jlivingood
issues.body:
Connection attribute is currently defined as:
> cable: A cable connection.
fixed: A fixed-line connection (e.g fiber, metro-Ethernet).
cellular: A cellular connection.
satellite: A satellite connection.
wireless: A wireless connection.
other: Any other type of connection. ((TODO (WK): I suspect that there is already a list of connection types that we can just reference. In addition, I suspect we should just list connection attributes, such as latency, bandwidth, "cost", jitter, etc. Otherwise, we are going to have to keep updating this document every time someone invents a new connection type.))

Leveraging what I learned in developing a spec for machine-readable broadband labels and in publishing broadband maps, etc. the following may be better:
1. Access Network Connection Type
Indicates the access network technology used.
This field MUST be in the file and MUST be populated.
Field: connection_type
Type/Format: string
Examples: fixed, mobile, satellite

2. Network Technology Type.
This indicates the access network technology used for a given BIAS offering. This is a numeric field using
FCC-defined technology codes, limited to no more than 3 digits length. (In the future, it may be better to
register these codes with IANA and to maintain them globally, rather than on a regulator-specific basis.)
• If a Fixed plan type, refer to the FCC’s Fixed Technology Codes [42]. For example, hybrid-fiber coaxial
(HFC) is “40” and fiber to the premises (FTTP) is “50”.
• If a Mobile plan type, refer to the FCC’s Mobile Technology Codes [43]. For example, 3G is “300” and
5G is “500”. This field MUST be in the file and MUST be populated.
Note that mobile networks (and possibly other network types) may support the newest technology type, such
as 5G, while also remaining backward compatible with 4G and 3G. In such cases, the newest technology type
should be listed, because that is the current version/type of network.
This field MUST be in the file and MUST be populated.
Name: network_technology_type
Type/Format: numeric, range (0, 999)
Examples: 40, 50, 500

[42] “Fixed Technology Codes,” Federal Communications Commission (FCC), May 2023 [Online]. Available:
https://help.bdc.fcc.gov/hc/en-us/articles/5290793888795-Fixed-Technology-Codes
[43] “Mobile Technology Codes,” Federal Communications Commission (FCC), Jun. 2023 [Online]. Available:
https://help.bdc.fcc.gov/hc/en-us/articles/6673022944155-Mobile-Technology-Codes




See also [BITAG Machine Readable BB label specs](https://www.bitag.org/BITAG-BB-Labels.pdf)

issues.title: Timestamp and Versioning of File
issues.author: jlivingood
issues.body:
The spec currently has a version, which refers to the version of the standard. That is not the same as the version of the published file. Consumers need a way to know that a file is new - whether via a timestamp or file version. 

From the BITAG report on machine readable BB labels, which faced a similar issue, maybe this is helpful?

Date Published (_COULD be changed to Date+Time)_
Date when published in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), in the ISO 8601 format [40], with hyphens.
Thus the format is YYYY-MM-DD, so 2025-01-15 for example to represent January 15, 2025, according to
the current date in UTC.
This field MUST be in the file and MUST be used.
Name: date_published
Type/Format: date
Examples: 2025-01-15, 2025-11-02, 2025-06-06

[40] “ISO 8601 - Date and time — Representations for information interchange,” International Organization
for Standardization (ISO), Feb. 2019 [Online]. Available: https://www.iso.org/iso-8601-date-andtime-format.html

issues.title: Reporting Errors & Issues
issues.author: jlivingood
issues.body:
How can a consumer report an issue with a file? Perhaps via a Technical Support URI? (again adapting from a recent BITAG exercise)


Technical Support Information Uniform Resource Indicator (URI).
This is the URI containing information about how to obtain customer support for a specific BIAS offering.
This field MUST be in the file and MAY be populated. If it does not apply, it SHOULD be left empty.
Name: uri_geoip_support
Type/Format: identifier, uri
Examples: https://example.com/geoipsupport/internet/, https://example.com/geoipsupport, https://example.com/geoipsupport.html

issues.title: Universal Discovery?
issues.author: jlivingood
issues.body: How will consumers find ip geo feeds? Via a well-known URI? How will the URIs be discovered? From RIR data?

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body:
This is already covered in [[RFC9632 - "Finding and Using Geofeed Data"](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9632/)](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9632/) . For obvious reasons, this only covers [[RFC8805 - "A Format for Self-Published IP Geolocation Feeds"](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc8805/)](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc8805/) format, but the same solution works for whatever format (potentially with a new tag).

The way that this works is an address holder publishes their feed location in the RIR (using the "geofeed:" RPSL attribute, or the older "remarks   Geofeed:" if they havent updated yet).

Consumers ingest this data by downloading the RIR DB, running 'whois' for the address, or they can download all validated feeds at once from https://geolocatemuch.com/geofeeds/validated-all.csv.

Example using whois (for the IETF meeting network):
```
$ whois 31.130.224.1 | grep -i geo
remarks:        Geofeed https://noc.ietf.org/geo/google.csv
```

Or, using e.g RIPE's data (running `whois` for each prefix doesn't scale):
```
$ rg -A 18 'inetnum:        31.130.224.0'  ripe.db    

inetnum:        31.130.224.0 - 31.130.239.255
netname:        ietf-meeting-network
descr:          IETF Meeting Network
country:        CH
org:            ORG-IS136-RIPE
admin-c:        DUMY-RIPE
tech-c:         DUMY-RIPE
status:         ASSIGNED PI
mnt-by:         RIPE-NCC-END-MNT
mnt-by:         IETF-MNT
mnt-by:         netnod-mnt
mnt-routes:     ietf-mnt
mnt-domains:    ietf-mnt
notify:         ripedb-updates@noc.ietf.org
created:        2011-05-10T10:10:10Z
last-modified:  2021-08-31T18:46:35Z
source:         RIPE
remarks:        Geofeed https://noc.ietf.org/geo/google.csv
sponsoring-org: ORG-NIE1-RIPE
```

For a sense of scale, the RIPE database has ~44,000 geo-located prefixes:
```
rg --no-line-number -i geofeed ripe.db | wc -l  
   44107
``` 
and ~3,000 unique.

This is because many geofeed files contain multiple prefixes. For example, Hostinger publishes https://raw.githubusercontent.com/hostinger/geofeed/main/geofeed.csv , which contains ~800 prefixes. This is much of the reason for having an array in the JSON format.


Most CDNs / providers already ingest the RIR data for building routing policy, parsing AS-SETs, etc.
If they don't want to though, Massimo publishes a validated feeds at all of the data on https://geolocatemuch.com/

issues.title: Intersection of RPKI and IP Geo Feed Validation/Trust
issues.author: jlivingood
issues.body: Given widespread use of RPKI, can this be leveraged to or how does it relate to ip geo file validation and trust?

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body:
This is already covered by [[RFC9632 - "Finding and Using Geofeed Data"](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9632/)](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9632/)

There will likely need to be a note added on canonicalization, but the same solution applies.
